did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Laura Wise Maverick papers contain one scrapbook, a diary, and a travel journal documenting the singer's personal and professional life. Contained in the materials are programs from performances, playbills, announcements, news clippings, photographs, and personal documents belonging to Laura Wise Maverick.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Laura Wise Maverick (1878-1956) was born in San Antonio, Texas, to William H. Maverick and Emilia Virginia Chilton Maverick. Laura attended St. Mary's Hall Episcopal school, in San Antonio, and Wheaton Female Seminary in Norton, Massachusetts. On 1894 April 19, Laura married San Antonio doctor Amos Lawson Graves. They would have two children: Amos Maverick and Laura Maverick. Laura and her children moved to New York after she left, and later divorced, Amos Graves.

Laura was a talented contralto who toured and sang throughout the United States and Canada. She sang at Carnegie Hall, and debuted with the Russian Symphony Orchestra in 1912. Laura had a wide repertoire, singing in three languages, and was especially popular among New York and Texas concert goers. Laura later married Carl Hahn, a cellist, composer, and conductor, and the two toured and performed together during the 1910s. They would later divorce. They had no children.

The Maverick name is synonymous with the Texas Revolution and early Texas history. Laura would continue to enhance that name through her artistic contributions. Laura passed away on 1956 January 31 at the age of 77 and is buried in Mission Burial Park South in San Antonio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Laura Wise Maverick papers contain materials documenting her personal and professional life, with the bulk of the papers concentrated in 1911-1913, and 1933-1937. The largest item is a scrapbook containing programs, playbills, announcements, news clippings, and press releases detailing Laura's performances, along with some loose materials from her childhood, including her diploma, and a few photographs. A diary, dated 1933-1937, gives some insight into Laura's tour travels and daily life. She speaks of the weather, friends and family, and colleagues throughout the pages. Her tour journal has no date associated with it, but documents an early US tour beginning in Texas, then traveling to the West Coast and from there to the East Coast. She speaks of cars, travel methods, time spent on the road, places and colleagues visited and events attended throughout the journal.

This collection contains information on the Maverick family and will be useful to researchers in that area as well as those interested in early travel in modern America The collection also documents the experiences of women working in theater and music in the early 1900s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection was arranged in no particular order upon arrival. Currently, the papers are arranged in one series: Personal Materials.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The personal materials series contains the scrapbook, diary, and travel journal of Laura Wise Maverick, documenting the personal and professional life of the Texas contralto. Included in these materials are programs, press releases, playbills, news clippings, photographs, and personal documents.
